questions.text: In which of the following situations is succinylcholine most likely to cause severe hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
• Conditions
    1. denervation injury / spinal cord injury leading to skeletal muscle atrophy;
    2. skeletal muscle injury resulting from third-degree burns (until scarring occurs);
    3. acute upper motor neuron injury such as stroke;
    4. severe skeletal muscle trauma; and
    5. severe abdominal infections.
  • In these - increase potassium levels -takes a few days to develop, peaks 10 to 50 days after the initial injury, and may persist for 6 months or more.
  • so, more than 24 hours after avoid

The LEAST likely side effect of dexmedetomidine in a healthy patient is
Postanaesthetic shivering can be treated with all of the following EXCEPT
The main disadvantage of Sugammadex compared with neostigmine is
questions.solution:
Sugammadex

  • SRBA(selective relaxant binding agent)
  • Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin (cyclic oligosaccharide) compound that encapsulates nondepolarizing steroidal muscle relaxants
  • (rocuronium > vecuronium >> pancuronium) and produces rapid reversal of profound block (e.g., reversal of 0.6 mg/kg rocuronium in 3 minutes).
  • Dose - 2 to 16 mg/kg
  • MOA
    • 1:1
    • No autonomic SE or affected by Body s status
    • Complex excreted unchanged in urine

questions.text: The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is highest in neonates (0-30 days old) versus other age groups with which of the following?
questions.solution:
• MAC - varies with age.
  • Most volatile anesthetics, MAC values are highest @ > 1m to < 6m of age
  • But,. For sevoflurane, the MAC for neonates 0 to 30 days old is 3.3%, for infants 1 to 6 months old it is 3.2%, and for infants 6 to 12 months old it is 2.5%

choices.text: Its propensity to produce hypertension in high concentrations
Its propensity to produce airway irritability

questions.text: The main reason desflurane is not used for inhalation induction in clinical practice is because of
Which of the following volatile anesthetics decreases systemic vascular resistance?
With which of the following inhalational agents is cardiac output moderately increased?
questions.solution:
• Halothane - decrease the CO
  • Sevoflurane, Desflurane, and Isoflurane - maintain CO.
  • N2O -increase, CO - increase in sympathetic tone

questions.text: Select the FALSE statement about isoflurane (≤ 1 MAC).
questions.solution:
• CO - unchanged because decreases in systemic vascular resistance result in a reflex increase in heart rate
  • At 1 MAC, isoflurane
    • May attenuate antigen-induced bronchospasm, presumably by decreasing vagal tone.
    • No change in CO
  • >1 MAC - SV and CI Decrease

questions.text: Abrupt and large increases in the delivered concentration of which of the following inhalational anesthetics may produce transient increases in systemic blood pressure and heart rate?
You have given a supraclavicular block in a patient for an upper limb surgery, following which patient complaints of difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Although all these complications are possible with a supraclavicular block, most common complication is ipsilateral phrenic nerve palsy. Nearly half of patients undergoing supraclavicular block will experience ipsilateral phrenic nerve palsy, although ultrasound guidance may decrease this incidence by allowing use of minimal local anesthetic volume.

Complications & side-effects of supraclavicular block:

  • Hemi diaphragmatic paresis - due to phrenic nerve palsy
  • Pneumothorax - highest among brachial plexus block
  • Horner's syndrome - from block of the stellate ganglion
  • Hoarseness - due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy and/or cervical sympathetic block

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anesthesiology 6th edition pg 1010.

questions.text: Isoflurane, when administered to healthy patients in concentrations less than 1.0 MAC, will decrease all of the following EXCEPT

choices.text: Use of blood less than 14 days old

questions.text: Which of the measures below does NOT reduce the incidence of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)?
questions.solution:
TRALI

Occurs within 6 hours of blood component administration.

Noncardiogenic pulmonary edema

Acute bilateral pulmonary infiltrates

Hypoxemia (PaO2/FIO2) ≤ 300 mm Hg

Oxygen saturation ≤ 90% on room air

No evidence of left atrial hypertension

  • The pathologic changes involve lowpressure pulmonary edema secondary to neutrophil activation and sequestration in the lungs.
  • Older transfusion products (> 14 days),
  • female donors (especially multiparous patients), and pooled platelets compared
  • Because donor antibodies are the usual cause, leukocyte reduction does not decrease the incidence of TRALI but does decrease the incidence of febrile reactions and the risk of CMV, and it may decrease leukocyte-induced immunomodulation.
  • Treatment for TRALI reactions is supportive.

choices.text: It reduces the chance for infection
It decreases the incidence of allergic reactions

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a BMS in the mid portion of the LADA is scheduled for rotator cuff repair under GA. The stent was placed 6 weeks before surgery, and the patient is on dual therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel). Which of the paradigms below would be best for managing his anticoagulation before surgery?
questions.solution:
The elective procedure is delayed for

  • At least 2 weeks after balloon angioplasty without a stent,
  • 6 weeks after a bare-metal stent, and
  • 12 months after a drug-eluting stent

The clopidogrel is stopped and restarted as soon as possible after the surgery (aspirin is usually continued).

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese patient has diminished breath sounds bilaterally at the lung bases 18 hours after an emergency appendectomy under general anesthesia. Which of the following maneuvers would be LEAST effective in preventing postoperative pulmonary complications in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased venous return to the heart
Increased afterload on the right side of the heart
Increased afterload on the left side of the heart

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient is mechanically ventilated in the ICU 2 days after repair of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. To maintain PaO2 in the 60 to 65 range, 10 cm H2O positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is added to the ventilator cycle. The patient's blood pressure has averaged 110/65 before addition of PEEP. After addition of PEEP, the blood pressure is noted to slowly fall to an average of approximately 95/50. The best explanation for this decrease in blood pressure is
The MOST sensitive early sign of malignant hyperthermia (MH) during general anesthesia is
Which of the following is NOT a component of the postanesthetic discharge scoring system (PADSS) used to evaluate the suitability of a patient to be discharged from an ambulatory surgical facility?

A 45-year-old man is brought to the OR emergently for repair of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Anesthesia is induced with ketamine 2 mg/kg IV, and tracheal intubation is facilitated with succinylcholine 1.5 mg/kg IV. Immediately after tracheal intubation, the patient's blood pressure falls from 110/80 to 50/20 mm Hg. What is the MOST likely cause of the sudden severe hypotension in this patient?

choices.text: Damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman is undergoing a total thyroidectomy under general anesthesia. The patient is awakened in the OR, the mouth and pharynx are suctioned, and after intact laryngeal reflexes are demonstrated, the endotracheal tube is removed.
Two days later, the anesthesiologist is consulted because the patient has severe stridor and upper airway obstruction. The most likely cause of airway obstruction in this patient is
Remifentanil is metabolized primarily by

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation with 100% oxygen

questions.text: Brice Questionnaire is used to estimate

A 57-year-old man is undergoing a right eye enucleation under general anesthesia. The patient has no history of cardiac disease. During the operation, 5-mm ST-segment elevation is noted on lead II, and the patient develops complete heart block. The coronary artery most likely affected is

A 31-year-old patient has been in the ICU on a ventilator for 24 hours after an MVA. The patient does not open his eyes to any stimulus and has no verbal or motor response. The Glasgow Coma Scale corresponding to this patient would be
Which of the following is most likely to be associated with a falsely elevated SaO2 as measured by pulse oximetry (dual wave)?
questions.solution:
• 660-nm red light and 940-nm infrared light.
  • Carboxyhemoglobin -produces a falsely elevated SaO2 when present in the blood.
  • Hemoglobin F, bilirubin, and fluorescein dye -no effect -
  • Methylene blue, as well as indigo carmine and indocyanine green, low-SaO2 values
  • Methemoglobin absorbs red and infrared light equally well and gives saturation readings of 85%

It does not occur in the absence of hypothermia

questions.text: Each of the following statements regarding postoperative shivering is true EXCEPT
ECG changes associated with hyperkalemia include

Anesthesia is induced in a 50-year-old, 125-kg man for anterior cervical fusion. The patient is placed on a ventilator. Peak airway pressure is noted to be 20 cm H2 O with O2 saturation 99% on pulse oximeter. An hour later, the peak airway pressure rises to 40 cm H2 O and PaCO2 is 38 mm Hg on infrared spectrometer and on O2 saturation falls to 88%. Blood pressure and heart rate are unchanged. The MOST likely cause of these findings is
